topics.body:
One of the very few (and I mean, extremely very) motivational speeches I've heard was when I was 13 years old and this dude compared human beings to three different food items.

A carrot.
An egg.
Some coffee beans.

He then pulls out a pot full of hot water and says that this is the hardship and experiences or life. He first puts the carrot in and it comes out soggy. He later puts the egg in and it becomes hard-boiled. Finally, he puts the coffee beans and it becomes, well, coffee.



The carrot was a strong figure, both inside and out. He was brave and skilled and pretty much just great. But when faced with the hardships of life, he became weak and soggy and just tired. He was no longer strong and it was a bit humiliating to see him like that.

The egg had a hard shell, but was fragile. The inside was soft and loving, that's one of its traits. But when faced with the hardships of life, he became hard and just a plain old jerk. His inside was rock solid and no longer soft. He hated a lot of things and was arrogant and ignorant. He probably even hated his old self. Maybe even his current self.

The coffee beans were different than the two. Before facing all that hardships, he was just average. There was nothing special about him that's worth mentioning. But then, the coffee beans disappeared and in its place was a beautiful aroma and surprisingly nice colour. Instead of life changing him, he changed life itself. He faced a lot of hardships and ultimately disappeared. But he left a mark in the world and that mark was something beautiful. Life became beautiful, even though he wasn't there to see it.

So, the speech giver asked us which one of these is us. It's obvious what we would answer.
topics.author: 4fe1b9f47f123b13df002976

topics.body:
How about a compromise then?
People tend to be more responsive to genres they like cause that's the sort of stories they like and that if a person tries at least a sizable portion of a franchise, except if it's fucking hugely impossible for one person to get into, it's fair for them to gauge whether or not they like it if they've gotten far enough in to determine whether or not they like that sort of story.
